explanation:
The report is speculative and not proven by the code shown. The MHD_add_response_header function itself does not directly call any <string.h> routines — it calls a helper MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (and other internal helpers). MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is concerned with actual uses of the standard string functions that can read past object bounds. To demonstrate a violation you must show one of two things: (a) MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (or another called helper) actually invokes an unsafe string.h routine (e.g. strcmp/strlen/memcmp without explicit bounds) in a way that can read past the end of the object, or (b) that the pointer passed (header) may legitimately point to a non-NUL-terminated buffer or a buffer shorter than the compared literal so that even a correct implementation would read out of bounds.

Agent A's scenario is a plausible hypothetical (if MHD_str_equal_caseless_ uses unbounded strcmp/strlen and the caller can pass non-NUL-terminated data, an out-of-bounds read could occur), but the target code as shown does not prove that. Without the implementation of MHD_str_equal_caseless_ or evidence that header may be non–NUL-terminated, you cannot conclude a MISRA 21.17 violation. If you want to establish a real violation, provide the implementation of MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (showing unsafe string.h usage) or show that header/content may be non‑terminated, or otherwise ensure comparisons are done with explicit bounds (e.g. strncasecmp/memcmp with known lengths) or document/validate the NUL-terminated precondition.

Therefore the report is not correct as presented (insufficient evidence of an actual Rule 21.17 breach).
